channel.title: Comments on: Baklava with Homemade Phyllo Pastry – Daring Bakers Challenge June 2011

item.title: By: Pauli
item.dc:creator: Pauli
item.description: My yiayia made her own filo dough from scratch. The resulting dough ball was roughly the size of her fist. when she rolled it out, it covered the (large) kitchen table. The test to see if it was thin enough was if you could read a newspaper through it. :) I still miss her. She layered it with 6-8 leaves of filo as the base, then each sheet was lightly spread with the melted butter and about 1/4 c of filling, repeating till the top of the pan, where again, there were 6-8 sheets of filo layered with a thin spread of melted butter. While cutting most of the way through the filo (hint #1 in Melli's comment), she always used a whole clove pushed through the top center of the diamond shape, for structure and for flavor, and didn't use any ground cloves. It is a Turkish recipe, but since Turkey occupied Greece for hundreds of years, the Greeks made it Greek. :)
item.content:encoded: My yiayia made her own filo dough from scratch. The resulting dough ball was roughly the size of her fist. when she rolled it out, it covered the (large) kitchen table. The test to see if it was thin enough was if you could read a newspaper through it. ðŸ™‚ I still miss her. She layered it with 6-8 leaves of filo as the base, then each sheet was lightly spread with the melted butter and about 1/4 c of filling, repeating till the top of the pan, where again, there were 6-8 sheets of filo layered with a thin spread of melted butter. While cutting most of the way through the filo (hint #1 in Melli’s comment), she always used a whole clove pushed through the top center of the diamond shape, for structure and for flavor, and didn’t use any ground cloves. It is a Turkish recipe, but since Turkey occupied Greece for hundreds of years, the Greeks made it Greek. ðŸ™‚

item.title: By: Melli
item.dc:creator: Melli
item.description: Your baklava looks lovely! Kudos for making your own phyllo. Having grown up making baklava at least twice every year since I could stand at a counter, I will give you two bits of advice: #1: Do not cut all the way through to the bottom of the pan. Leave the bottom layer intact so the phyllo does not get soggy from the syrup. #2: The syrup soaks into the pastry best if one is hot and one is cold. It doesn't matter which is hot but one must be.
item.content:encoded: Your baklava looks lovely! Kudos for making your own phyllo. Having grown up making baklava at least twice every year since I could stand at a counter, I will give you two bits of advice: #1: Do not cut all the way through to the bottom of the pan. Leave the bottom layer intact so the phyllo does not get soggy from the syrup. #2: The syrup soaks into the pastry best if one is hot and one is cold. It doesn’t matter which is hot but one must be.

item.title: By: Bouchra
item.dc:creator: Bouchra
item.description:
WOW! this recipe looks amazing! I am a huge fan of Baklava and always wanted to make my own rather than buying it from the store . I am looking forward making your recipe and I can't wait to try it. Yummy!
Cheers.
Bouchra
item.content:encoded:

item.title: By: Kari@Loaves n Dishes
item.dc:creator: Kari@Loaves n Dishes
item.description: I saw this on Pinterest, and when I noticed that the title said Homemade Phyllo dough I came straight over to see for myself! This looks so syrupy and delicious, and I'm especially excited to make the phyllo dough!
item.content:encoded: I saw this on Pinterest, and when I noticed that the title said Homemade Phyllo dough I came straight over to see for myself! This looks so syrupy and delicious, and I’m especially excited to make the phyllo dough!

item.title: By: Lorraine
item.dc:creator: Lorraine
item.description: This was delicious!! although I did use store bought dough. MMMMMMMMM!!!
item.content:encoded: This was delicious!! although I did use store bought dough. MMMMMMMMM!!!

item.title: By: Jamie Asper
item.dc:creator: Jamie Asper
item.description: Your Baklava looks really good. I once worked with a Russian man whose wife made it for us all at work. The recipe was 2000 years old. It was amazing!! I have had Baklava many times at Resturants and nothing has ever tasted quite like that recipe. I always seearch for that same flavour though. Found your post on Pinterest. Have a great day! ~ Jamie
item.content:encoded: Your Baklava looks really good. I once worked with a Russian man whose wife made it for us all at work. The recipe was 2000 years old. It was amazing!! I have had Baklava many times at Resturants and nothing has ever tasted quite like that recipe. I always seearch for that same flavour though. Found your post on Pinterest. Have a great day! ~ Jamie

item.title: By: Kelly
item.dc:creator: Kelly
item.description: this looks SO SO SO good.

item.title: By: Tro
item.dc:creator: Tro
item.description: FYI - I often make Baklava (with store bought dough), but my recipie calls for a 12 oz jar of honey instead of making a syrup mixture. It gets drizzled on the same way after baking. However, it tastes just a good and you don't have the runny syrup. Might want to try it! I'm going to try the phyllo dough!
item.content:encoded:
FYI –
I often make Baklava (with store bought dough), but my recipie calls for a 12 oz jar of honey instead of making a syrup mixture. It gets drizzled on the
same way after baking. However, it tastes just a good and you don’t have the runny syrup. Might want to try it! I’m going to try the phyllo dough!

item.title: By: bahar006

item.description: Baklava is a TurkÄ±sh recipe and all the families make Baklava in the morning of the Ramadan Feast. We also make this to our special.guests. Ä°n Turkey Gaziantep city is famous with its pistachio Baklava. Your Baklava seems delicios, loves from Ankara:)

item.description: Great recipe! Simple to follow and the baklava turned out delicious. Thank you!
item.content:encoded: Great recipe! Simple to follow and the baklava turned out delicious. Thank you!
